summary: This document set comprises US Marshals Service booking, custody, and medical forms for Jeffrey Epstein following his arrest on July 8, 2019. It includes his personal history, arrest warrant, custody details, and medical release forms, documenting his initial processing into federal custody on sex trafficking charges. This document is a collection of forms and receipts related to the U.S. Marshals Service filing a Notice of Lis Pendens (Notice of Pendency) against Jeffrey Epstein's property at 9 East 71st Street, New York, owned by Maple Inc. It includes the legal notice, filing receipts, and internal procurement vouchers for services related to the asset forfeiture process as part of criminal case 19 CR 490. This document contains a Notice of Pendency for the forfeiture of Jeffrey Epstein's New York mansion at 9 East 71st Street, the sealed indictment charging him with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors, and a US Marshals Service subject report on Epstein. The indictment details a multi-year scheme to sexually exploit dozens of minor girls in New York and Florida, using a network of employees and victim-recruiters. This document is a compilation of US Marshals Service (USMS) reports detailing the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's failure to report international travel as a registered sex offender, witness interviews regarding sightings of him with young girls, and administrative records related to his custody and death. The investigation was closed following his suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the USMS investigation for failing to report international travel. He was in custody for federal sex trafficking charges and died by suicide on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Barbara Moses
persons.context: Issued the arrest warrant for Jeffrey Epstein on July 2, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary defendant charged with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors. The indictment alleges he sexually exploited dozens of minor girls at his residences in New York and Florida from at least 2002 to 2005.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed and filed the Notice of Pendency against Epstein's property.

persons.name: Stacy Rider
persons.context: An administrative officer for the U.S. Marshals Service who certified the availability of funds for the filing fee on a procurement requisition form.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Listed as an associate (brother) of Jeffrey Epstein in the US Marshals Service subject report.

persons.name: Senior Inspector (SI)
persons.context: Lead investigator who conducted witness interviews, coordinated with AUSAs, and managed the investigation into Epstein's travel violations.

persons.name: Miami Herald reporter
persons.context: Provided information and an informant's contact to the USMS regarding sightings of Epstein with young girls at an airport.

persons.name: Air Traffic Controller (informant)
persons.context: An air traffic controller who reported seeing Epstein disembark from his plane with young girls, aged approximately 11-18, between June/July and November 2018.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Federal prosecutor in the US Virgin Islands with whom the USMS coordinated regarding MLAT requests and the investigation. The case was dropped after Epstein's death.

connections.description: Berman, as the U.S. Attorney, is the prosecuting authority initiating forfeiture proceedings against Epstein's property as part of the criminal case.
Epstein directed Employee-1, a New York-based employee, to communicate with victims to schedule sexual encounters at the New York residence.
Epstein arranged for Employee-2 to contact victims to schedule encounters at the Palm Beach residence. Employee-2 made calls from New York to victims in Florida.
Employee-3, an assistant at the Palm Beach residence, placed calls to schedule sexual encounters with minor victims.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-1 at the New York residence, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls. He asked her age and she answered truthfully.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-2 at the Palm Beach residence, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-3 at the Palm Beach residence, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls. He asked her age and she answered truthfully.
Mark Epstein is listed as Jeffrey Epstein's brother in the US Marshals Service subject report.
The Senior Inspector was the lead USMS investigator looking into Epstein's potential violations of international travel reporting laws.
The reporter provided the USMS with information from the air traffic controller, who was her informant regarding sightings of Epstein.
The SI interviewed the reporter to gather leads and potential witness information for the Epstein investigation.
The SI coordinated with the AUSA's office on legal aspects of the investigation, including submitting MLAT requests and discussing case strategy.

events.title: Arrest Warrant Issued
events.description: US Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses issues an arrest warrant for Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Arrest and Booking
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is arrested by the FBI and processed into US Marshals Service custody. Booking photos and forms are completed.

events.title: Federal Custody
events.description: Epstein is held in federal custody, initially at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, for 33 days.

events.title: Custody Status Change
events.description: Epstein's custody status is marked with 'SUICIDE' and 'CASE-RESOLVED' remarks, coinciding with the date of his death.

events.title: Filing of Notice of Pendency
events.description: The United States Attorney's Office files a Notice of Lis Pendens against the property at 9 East 71st Street, New York, owned by Maple Inc., as part of the forfeiture proceedings in case 19 CR 490 against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: County Clerk Filing and Fee Payment
events.description: The Notice of Pendency is officially filed with the New York County Clerk's Office, and a $35.00 filing fee is paid by the U.S. Marshals Service.

events.title: Beginning of Sex Trafficking Conspiracy
events.description: The indictment alleges Jeffrey Epstein began enticing and recruiting dozens of minor girls to engage in sex acts with him at his New York and Florida residences.

events.title: Abuse of Minor Victim-1 and Scheduling Call
events.description: Epstein abused Minor Victim-1 at the New York residence. Employee-1, on behalf of Epstein, placed a call to Minor Victim-1 to schedule an appointment for paid sex acts.

events.title: Abuse of Minor Victim-3 and Scheduling Calls
events.description: Epstein abused Minor Victim-3 at the Palm Beach residence. Employee-2 and Employee-3 placed calls to Minor Victim-3 to schedule appointments for paid sex acts.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in Florida of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution (F.S. 796.03) and sentenced to 13 months incarceration, requiring lifetime sex offender registration.

events.title: Epstein Reports Travel to France
events.description: Epstein reported to the US Virgin Islands Sex Offender Registry that he would be traveling to France from March 19 to March 29, 2019, via his private jet (N212JE).

events.title: Unreported Travel to Vienna
events.description: Flight tracking data showed Epstein's jet traveled to Vienna, Austria, a destination not listed on his official travel notification form.

events.title: Unreported Travel to Monaco
events.description: Flight tracking data showed Epstein's jet traveled to Monaco, a destination not listed on his official travel notification form.

events.title: Interview with Miami Herald Reporter
events.description: USMS inspectors interviewed a Miami Herald reporter who provided leads, including an airport informant who witnessed Epstein with young girls.

events.title: Interview with Air Traffic Controller
events.description: A Senior Inspector interviewed an air traffic controller who witnessed Epstein disembark from his plane with young girls on multiple occasions in 2018.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide while in federal custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: Case Closure
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the USMS and the US Virgin Islands AUSA's office agreed to drop the investigation, canceling all pending warrants, MLAT requests, and investigative activities.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on July 8, 2019, by the FBI on federal charges of sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors (18 USC §§ 371, 1591).
The arrest warrant was issued by US Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses on July 2, 2019, in the Southern District of New York (Case No. 19-CR-00490).
Epstein was held in US Marshals Service custody for 33 days, from July 8, 2019, to August 10, 2019, primarily at the MCC in New York.
The custody documents note 'Suicidal Tendencies' and 'Mental Concerns' as special cautions for Epstein, and his custody record ends on August 10, 2019, with remarks of 'SUICIDE' and 'CASE-RESOLVED'.
The documents include extensive personal identification details, addresses in New York, Florida, and the US Virgin Islands, and references to his Medicare and passport information.
The U.S. government initiated asset forfeiture proceedings against Jeffrey Epstein's New York City mansion at 9 East 71st Street, owned by the entity Maple Inc.
The legal action is tied to criminal case 19 CR 490, indicating it is part of the 2019 federal indictment against Epstein.
The Notice of Pendency (Lis Pendens) was filed on July 8, 2019, by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman to secure the government's claim on the property during the forfeiture process.

The U.S. Marshals Service ordered and paid for a 'Pre-Seizure Package' of services including a Pre-Seizure Analysis, Residential Desktop Brokers Price Opinion, and Preliminary Title Commitment for the property, totaling $1,092.00.
The property is described with precise legal boundaries and identified on the NYC tax map as Block 1386, Lot 10 in Manhattan.
The indictment charges Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors, alleging he abused dozens of girls as young as 14 from at least 2002 to 2005.
Epstein used a network of employees (Employee-1, Employee-2, Employee-3) to schedule sexual encounters with victims and paid victims hundreds of dollars in cash per encounter.
Epstein encouraged victims to recruit other minor girls, creating a "vast network" of underage victims, and paid these victim-recruiters for each new girl they brought.
The US government is seeking forfeiture of Epstein's New York mansion at 9 East 71st Street, owned by Maple, Inc., as property used to facilitate the crimes.
A US Marshals Service report lists Epstein's personal details, addresses, and associates, including his brother Mark Epstein, and notes he is a lifetime sex offender registrant in NY and Florida.
The US Marshals Service was investigating Jeffrey Epstein for potential violations of 18 USC 2250(b) for failing to report all international travel as required by International Megan's Law.
A key witness, an air traffic controller, reported seeing Epstein get off his plane with young girls, some appearing to be as young as 11-12 years old, between June/July and November 2018.
Flight data revealed Epstein traveled to Vienna, Austria and Monaco in March 2019, countries he did not report on his official travel notification form which only listed France.
The investigation was active and pursuing search warrants for Epstein's phone and international MLAT requests at the time of his death on August 10, 2019.
Following Epstein's suicide, the USMS and prosecutors agreed to drop the case, canceling all investigative activities and closing the file.
